I say Jeeves! What the Dickens has made us so popular?

18/07/2012

Rekindle your penchant for Wodehouse's escapist idealism this Summer, says Tom Witherow

Image by

By undefined undefined

"I marmaladed a slice of toast with something of a flourish, and I don't suppose I have ever come much closer to saying 'Tra-la-la' as I did the lathering, for I was feeling in mid-season form." This is the sentence that opens P.G. Wodehouse's twelfth book recounting tales from the life of one Bertie Wilberforce Wooster. Beautifully imaginative prose, one might say. But can we really say it is deserved of a place in the hearts of today's bookworms? Wodehouse was born in 1881, and would have followed in his brother's footsteps, going to Oxford, had a fall in the rupee not scuppered his father's finances. He was found a position at the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, now HSBC. However, he was never interested in banking and returned to England to be a journalist, contributing to the Globe, Punch and Vanity Fair. But it was not until Something Fresh was serialised in the Saturday Evening Post that he had his break. In 1939, Wodehouse and his family were living in France. Perhaps due to his disinterest in politics, or the fact that his wife couldn't bear to leave their dog Wonder, they remained there as war broke out. He was captured and interned in Belgium and then Upper Silesia. From here he released talks designed for American radio. Controversy erupted in England - it was thought this comedy might act counter to propaganda attempting to de-humanize the Nazis.
Some awfully nice Nazi asked me to do a radio show so I thought I'd keep everyone's spirits up by making a few jolly remarks about the food in Germany and now I hear everyone back home thinks I'm a collaborator.
Wodehouse was eventually cleared of treason, but the bad taste was not forgotten as he eloped to live out his final days in New York. Jeeves and Wooster are the most famous comic creations of Wodehouse's. Many have commented on his work: Hitchens called him 'the gold standard of English wit' and Brett admitted 'drooling with admiration' at his prose. But they are also the most enduring. How is it possible that these stories, centering on the gallivanting of the Edwardian upper classes, hold such popularity now? What in our current experience enables us to relate to Wodehouse's imagined vision of Mayfair's gentry? For having woken to a life-affirming cup of tea and dealt with Jeeves's toothsome eggs and b., Bertram flits between the Drones club, the Ritz and the Savoy Grill. He runs errands for the dreaded Aunt Agatha, hoping she doesn't arrange another engagement for him, or the 'aged relative' Aunt Dahlia, on the promise of another helping of that 'great artist' Anatole's cooking. Where else could the names Barmy Fotheringay-Phipps (pronounced Fungy-Phipps) and Augustus Fink-Nottle be at home? Or indeed the locations: Totleigh-in-the-Wold and Market Snodsbury? Place Wooster and co's incessant making and breaking of engagements beside all the what-ho-ing, toodle-pipping and tinkerty-tonking and you really do have a remarkable and alien social situation. So where does the attraction lie? Well firstly, there is an ever-present sunshine in the land of Jeeves that allows for the reader to escape any of the troubling woes of the real world. Colonel Norman Murphy, ex-President of the P.G. Wodehouse Society, sees this as central to its universal success: "Everyone likes fairy stories, everyone likes happy endings. And you can compare them to that. Very funny language which made people laugh just by the words themselves." And indeed even when Bingo Little ends up waist high in the soup, usually an undesirable engagement or the cutting of his allowance, one always knows that the great mind of Jeeves will find a solution. Next, we may have to admit that we feel a sense of nostalgia towards the idyllic world the characters inhabit. Series such as Downton Abbey demonstrate that sometimes there are aspects of this period of the past which we miss. Of course, those things best forgotten are blissfully absent from Wodehouse's world. Although technically the war is approaching at the time in which the novels are set, the only allusions are comic. Who else but Wodehouse could have called the leader of the Blackshirts ('Blackshorts' in the book) a 'frightful ass swanking about in footer bags!' However, the minutiae of Wodehouse's plots are easily forgotten. The moment the last page is turned, one forgets who was engaged to whom and what Jeeves's plan of escape actually consisted of. But this merely allows one to read Wodehouse's playful English once more. It is interesting that he considered the plot the hardest part to write: "Writing my stories I enjoy. It is the thinking them out that is apt to blot the sunshine from my life." "You can't think out plots like mine without getting the suspicion from time to time that something has gone seriously wrong with the brain's two hemispheres and the broad band of transversely running fibres known as the corpus callosum." He noted ideas endlessly, once claiming that he wrote 400 pages before he even put pen to paper. In this way it is the words and the inherent comedy which justify their popularity. Colonel Murphy expands: "He made people laugh for seventy years, without recourse to sex, violence, or cruelty. Think of Tolstoy. He wrote great ideas in a dull way. Wodehouse wrote about rubbish in a very clever way. People admire both but what they now admit that Wodehouse was great as well because he wrote rubbish so well."
'"Tinkety tonk," I said, and I meant it to sting.' "I ask you: how is one to do justice of even the roughest sort to a line like that?"
Many comic pairings bring together a fool and someone equally, if not slightly more, foolish. Think Blackadder and Baldrick, Laurel and Hardy, Basil Fawlty and Manuel or Del Boy and Rodney. But Wodehouse allows Wooster to narrate while the fish-eating brainbox tacitly manipulates and mocks. The genius of Sir Humphrey immediately springs to mind. Perhaps however, we should not be so surprised at his success as playful writers of prose have been very successful in the UK. Take Terry Pratchett, who has just released the 39th novel of his Discworld series, whose success one could argue is based on his imaginative use of the English language to tell stories and create humour. Evelyn Waugh's popularity has also lasted - indeed one could say that these masters of the comic novel, and the many others not mentioned here, rely on their grasp of the English language. However, what many authors have failed to do, and Waugh is of course a notable exception in this case, is have their work adapted to screen as successfully as Wodehouse. It is the small screen that allowed Jeeves and Wooster to gain the renown that they now enjoy. And one must give credit to Fry and Laurie for bringing the characters' world to life. Hugh Laurie, although I'm sure aware of the success of the programme which ran for four series, does not believe it has anything on the books. "The thing which really worried us was The Words." He makes reference to one of Bertie's lines from 'What-ho, Jeeves': '"Tinkety tonk," I said, and I meant it to sting.' Laurie seems incredulous that any scriptwriter should expect him to attempt it. "I ask you: how is one to do justice of even the roughest sort to a line like that? How can any human actor, with his clumsily attached ears, and his irritating voice, and his completely misguided hair, hope to deliver a line as pure as that? It cannot be done. You begin with a diamond on the page, and you end up with a blob of Pritt, The Non-Sticky Sticky Stuff, on the screen." Colonel Murphy is unhesitant in condemning the shows, saying that although "Hugh Laurie was by far the best Bertie Wooster we ever had, Wodehouse doesn't work on the screen, it can't be done." So many of the lines in Wodehouse need to be thought about, digested in one's own time. You might attempt to declaim it yourself (although I don't think I've ever managed to put 'what' at the end of a sentence while keeping a straight face, as in "so here we are, what?"), or simply partake in Brett's drooling. Laurie describes this with characteristic wit: "If I may go slightly culinary for a moment: a dish of foie gras nestling on a bed of truffles, with a side-order of lobster and caviar may provide you with a wonderful sensation; but no matter how wonderful, you simply don't want to be spoon-fed the stuff by a perfect stranger. You need to hold the spoon, and decide for yourself when to wolf and when to nibble." And so it is the books to which we are encouraged to return. However, there is more to be enjoyed than just Jeeves, as Stephen Fry writes: 'had his only contribution to literature been Lord Emsworth and Blandings Castle, his place in history would have been assured. Had he written of none but Mike and Psmith, he would be cherished today as the best and brightest of our comic authors. If Jeeves and Wooster had been his solitary theme, still he would be hailed as the Master. That he gave us all those - and more - is our good fortune and a testament to the most industrious, prolific and beneficent author ever to have sat down, scratched his head and banged out a sentence.' Shortly before his death, Wodehouse famously said that he had no ambitions left, having been knighted in the 1975 New Year's honours list and created as a wax figure at Madame Tussaud's. Perhaps these were meant as a way of apologising to a man so tortured by the idea that he was considered a traitor. "There's been this awful confusion. Some awfully nice Nazi asked me to do a radio show so I thought I'd keep everyone's spirits up by making a few jolly remarks about the food in Germany and now I hear everyone back home thinks I'm a collaborator. Nothing could be further from the truth. I'm having a perfectly miserable time." Perhaps the recent printing of the tenth edition of Jeeves would have put his mind at rest.
